abstract.p: South Carolina Gov Jim Hodges, in unusual live statewide television broadcast, signs compromise law that removes Confederate battle flag from state Capitol dome; credits NAACP boycott for bringing attention to issue; does not mention that NAACP is still boycotting state because it considers flag's new site, in front of statehouse, too prominent (S)

block.p: In an unusual live statewide television broadcast tonight, Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina signed into law a hard-won compromise that removes the Confederate battle flag from the dome of the state Capitol, where it has flown since 1962.
The flag will be lowered on July 1, and a smaller version of it will be raised near a Confederate memorial in front of the statehouse.

In an unusual live statewide television broadcast tonight, Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina signed into law a hard-won compromise that removes the Confederate battle flag from the dome of the state Capitol, where it has flown since 1962.
The flag will be lowered on July 1, and a smaller version of it will be raised near a Confederate memorial in front of the statehouse.

In remarks before the signing, the governor credited a tourism boycott called by the N.A.A.C.P. with bringing attention to the issue, though he did not mention that the organization is still boycotting the state because it considers the flag's new location too prominent. He said the flag is now in an appropriate historical context.

''Our state has been consumed by this debate,'' said Mr. Hodges, who called on legislators, who passed the bill last week, to move on to more pressing issues, such as public education and health care.
